TextView.android:text: 1. Alphabet Review 14 alphabet strokes have previously been covered. How quickly can you recognize them?

2. Brief Forms Some words in the English language appear repeatedly when we speak or write. To help with quick writing, special abbreviations called brief forms are used for some of these common words. This kind of abbreviation is often seen in handwritten work. For example, we shorten Street to St., Mister to Mr., and Saturday to Sat. Since these words with brief forms are used so often, it's important to learn them well.
*In- is also used as the start of words like:

• Have you noticed that some shorthand outlines can represent two or more words, such as are, our, and hour, or will and well? You won’t have any difficulty choosing the correct meaning in a sentence, because the context will make it clear.

3. Phrasing Using brief forms for common words helps you save time. Another way to increase writing speed is through a technique called phrasing, which means writing two or more shorthand outlines together as one unit. Below are several examples of phrases formed from the brief forms you have learned.

4. Left S-Z Earlier, you learned one form for s and another for z. There is also an additional stroke for s and z that allows easier joining with other strokes—a backward, downward comma shape known as the left s.\n\nAt this stage, you don’t need to worry about choosing which s stroke to use in a particular word; this will become clear as you continue your study of Gregg Shorthand.

5. P,B The shorthand stroke for p is a downward curve, shaped like the left s but larger—about half the height of the space between the lines in your shorthand notebook. The shorthand stroke for b is also a downward curve, similar in shape to the left s and p, but it is much larger—about the full height of the space between the lines in your notebook.
• Notice the difference in size among the s, p, and b strokes.
• Other combinations of strokes are also written in a single, smooth motion, just like p-r, p-l, b-r, and b-l, allowing for faster and more fluid shorthand writing.
